results.title: anywhere and here
results.credit_line:
Ian Burns
mixed media installation
ACMI Collection
results.brief_description:
‘anywhere and here’ is a suite of five interconnected kinetic sculptures which generate their own real-time video. It specifically explores the road movie genre, summoning familiar visions of the empty landscape, the wide open road and the car-in-motion, to destabilise powerful cinematic clichés.

‘anywhere and here’ was commissioned by ACMI and was exhibited at ACMI as “Ian Burns: In the Telling” in 2012-13.

Burns adapts existing appliances and domestic items and gives them new functions within his sculptures. This work draws meaning from the contrast between the projected image and the machinery out of which it is made.

The five sculptures that make up this work are linked via a video control system constructed by Burns and designed to switch between each of the structures at random. The images that are produced by the sculptures are projected onto the wall for the audience to view. Each scene generates its own live soundtrack. Burns has hacked an electronic keyboard to plunk out a simple music track. The keyboard becomes an integral part of the sculpture.

A shot of the moon suspended over water is based around a glass top table. The resulting optic effect simulates water movement and sparkle. A strip of plywood simulates the sky at dusk, while the moon is created by the projection of light through a hole in the wood.

On one end of a folding table the effect of a smoking chimney is generated using a plastic salad bowl with a LED light inside shining through a slit cut in the backing of a picture frame. The view from the camera is across a roll of hobby store brick print paper.

On the other end of the folding table, to simulate a high zoom shot of a plane passing overhead, Burns rotates a party store plastic salad bowl while a LED light inside the bowl generates the cloud effect. A fan usually used as a cooling device for a computer, generates the sound of the jet and shakes the camera to simulate the zoom effect on a hand-held camera.

A black vinyl chair has been stripped of all its vinyl until only a narrowing strip remains with slots cut out of it. The camera view of this under a red light gives it the look of a remote roadway in dry country.

The shot in close-up of a wheel with the white stripes of the road whizzing past is a road movie cliché. The sculpture is constructed out of an actual car wheel on a treadmill and a camera positioned to catch a cinematic view of the action.

The fifth sculpture comprises the central electronic system that guides the work as a whole.

results.title: Pathways
results.material_description: Multi-channel installation, video, projections, text, audio, bespoke screens, tiered  wooden seating , timber and LED strips
results.brief_description:
A collaboration between artist-filmmaker Jeff Doring and the Ngarinyin Aboriginal Corporation. This spatial installation provides access and insight into the art and culture of the Ngarinyin people. The intention is to record and interpret a broad spectrum of Ngarinyin knowledge and law. The work consists of five discrete and interrelated elements:
1. The Introduction zone: a space consisting of a text, audio, visual introduction to the installation.
2. The Water and Wanjina zone: a corridor with apertures that open on the side to reveal visual works.
3. The Man Blood Law zone: a three screen installation with tiered seating that lies at the end of the Water and Wanjina corridor.
4. The Cave zone: an exhibition space which spatially represents a cave with images projected inside it.
5. The Today zone: a space which provides a contemporary perspective on the exhibition via a web installation.

results.title: Hollywood Costume: Interview with Jan Chapman and Janet Patterson
results.creator_credit: Mike Kenneally, Csilla Csongvay, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
The 2009 film ‘Bright Star’ (directed by Jane Campion) tells the story of the romance between the English poet John Keats (1795 - 1821) and Fanny Brawne.
In this interview, ‘Bright Star’ producer Jan Chapman and costume designer Janet Patterson discuss the creative process behind costume design, and the design choices that went into making one of the costumes for the character Fanny Brawne (played in the film by Abbie Cornish).
The character’s crimson gown costume was on display during the ACMI Melbourne Winter Masterpieces ‘Hollywood Costume’ exhibition (2013).
Clips from ‘Bright Star’ (2009) courtesy of Hopscotch Films.

results.title: A Negroni.. Sbagliato...
results.material_description: Digital screen recording of Drawing Funny's YouTube post "What's Your Favourite Drink? A Negroni.. Sbagliato.. With Prosecco In It"
results.brief_description: When HBO posted a video of House of the Dragons stars Emma D’Arcy (Princess Rhaenyra Targaryen) and Olivia Cooke (Queen Alicent) discussing their favourite drinks, the internet collectively lost its mind. Video impersonations, memes, club mixes and queer tributes ensued on TikTok, Instagram and Twitter as the “stunning” broken negroni moment went viral.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

When HBO posted a video of House of the Dragon stars Emma D’Arcy (Princess Rhaenyra Targaryen) and Olivia Cooke (Queen Alicent) discussing their favourite drinks, the internet collectively lost its mind. Video impersonations, memes, club mixes and queer tributes ensued on TikTok, Instagram and Twitter as the “stunning” broken negroni moment went viral. The rhythm of the back-and-forth exchange has been adopted by social users as a template to prove a surprising point or argument that gradually escalates.
description_for_label: When HBO posted a video of House of the Dragon stars Emma D’Arcy (Princess Rhaenyra Targaryen) and Olivia Cooke (Queen Alicent) discussing their favourite drinks, the internet collectively lost its mind. Video impersonations, memes, club mixes and queer tributes ensued on TikTok, Instagram and Twitter as the “stunning” broken negroni moment went viral. The rhythm of the back-and-forth exchange has been adopted by social users as a template to prove a surprising point or argument that gradually escalates.

display_values: Digital screen recording of Drawing Funny's YouTube post "What's Your Favourite Drink? A Negroni.. Sbagliato.. With Prosecco In It"

results.title: GTA 6 in real life
results.brief_description: From TikToks of in-game successes (and failures) to live Twitch streams, social media and videogames are perfectly matched. Modern consoles often have built-in features that let users easily record their play to share online, but this video isn’t that. It looks like leaked footage of Grand Theft Auto 6’s new graphics, but it’s a real-world video mimicking the series’ old-school movements, gestures and streetscapes. It’s like digital cosplay and reflects a larger trend of social users recreating game worlds in real life – like giving strangers quests as if in a fantasy game – which highlights the blurring of online and offline life. It’s been viewed over 40m times and endlessly shared.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

From TikToks of in-game successes (and failures) to live Twitch streams, social media and videogames are perfectly matched. Modern consoles often have built-in features that let users easily record their play to share online, but this video isn’t that. It looks like leaked footage of Grand Theft Auto 6’s new graphics, but it’s a real-world video mimicking the series’ old-school movements, gestures and streetscapes. It’s like digital cosplay and reflects a larger trend of social users recreating game worlds in real life – like giving strangers side quests as if in GTA (embedded below) – which highlights the blurring of online and offline life. It’s been viewed over 40m times, but there are many versions out there. This TikTok from user @bryteosky features dialogue, sound effects, cinematic cut scenes, graphic overlays and an impressively large cast to further anchor reality to the game.
description_for_label: From TikToks of in-game successes (and failures) to live Twitch streams, social media and videogames are perfectly matched. Modern consoles often have built-in features that let users easily record their play to share online, but this video isn’t that. It looks like leaked footage of Grand Theft Auto 6’s new graphics, but it’s a real-world video mimicking the series’ old-school movements, gestures and streetscapes. It’s like digital cosplay and reflects a larger trend of social users recreating game worlds in real life – like giving strangers quests as if in a fantasy game – which highlights the blurring of online and offline life. It’s been viewed over 40m times and endlessly shared.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → MM-09. Catch of the Day

results.title: A Year to Remember 1953
results.brief_description: Collection of newsreel footage which made up Australia’s history in 1953 - Deaths of Stalin and Queen Mary - Coronation of Queen Elizabeth II - US Vice President Nixon visits Australia - Testing of the Jindivik at Woomera - Mt Everest conquered by Sir Edmund Hillary and Tensing - Anzac Day in Korea - Exchange of POW’s - Express train crash in New Zealand - Davis Cup wins by Lew Hoad and Ken Rosewall - Ben Hogan wins British Open … and much more. Rated: G

results.title: Forced into images
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour, silent
results.brief_description: In Destiny Deacon’s photographic series Forced into Images (a title taken from a poem by Alice Walker), a dramatic narrative unfolds that follows a girl’s troubled life from birth to womanhood. Deacon’s work often explores cultural stereotyping, domestic violence and the status of Indigenous women.

constellations_other.name: Women in charge
constellations_other.description: Across documentary, film, TV, and visual art, Aboriginal women have led how they will be represented on-screen.

results.description: DESTINY DEACON has shown in exhibitions including the 2001 Yokohama Triennale, Das Lied von der Erde at the Museum Fridericianum in Kassel, the 2000 Biennale of Sydney and the 1995 Havana Biennial and the Yokohoma triennial. Using people and objects close to her - friends and family, dolls and other toys - the artist creates strange, unsettling images that address some of the most difficult aspects of contemporary Australian life. Cultural stereotyping, domestic violence and the status of Aboriginal women all inform Deacon’s photography, and her gift for storytelling and biting sense of humour provide her work with a compelling edge. With her photographic series Forced into Images (a title taken from a poem by Alice Walker), a dramatic narrative unfolds, following a girl’s troubled life from birth to womanhood.
description_for_label: DESTINY DEACON has shown in exhibitions including the 2001 Yokohama Triennale, Das Lied von der Erde at the Museum Fridericianum in Kassel, the 2000 Biennale of Sydney and the 1995 Havana Biennial and the Yokohoma triennial. Using people and objects close to her - friends and family, dolls and other toys - the artist creates strange, unsettling images that address some of the most difficult aspects of contemporary Australian life. Cultural stereotyping, domestic violence and the status of Aboriginal women all inform Deacon’s photography, and her gift for storytelling and biting sense of humour provide her work with a compelling edge. With her photographic series Forced into Images (a title taken from a poem by Alice Walker), a dramatic narrative unfolds, following a girl’s troubled life from birth to womanhood.
